Suppose that  $\{a_n\}$ is an arithmetic sequence with $$
a_1+a_2+ \cdots +a_{100}=100 \quad \text{and} \quad
a_{101}+a_{102}+ \cdots + a_{200}=200.
$$What is the value of $a_2 - a_1$? Express your answer as a common fraction.
inference:
The sum of the first $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence is given by

$$S_n=\frac{n}{2}(a_1+a_n)$$

So, we have

$$S_{100}=\frac{100}{2}(a_1+a_{100})=100$$

and

$$S_{200}=\frac{200}{2}(a_{101}+a_{200})=200.$$

Since the first 100 terms of the sequence sum to 100 and the next 100 terms sum to 200, we have

$$a_1+a_{100}=2 \quad \text{and} \quad
a_{101}+a_{200}=4.$$

Therefore,

$$\begin{align*}
a_2-a_1&=a_1+1-a_1\\
&=1.
\end{align*}$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{1}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
We want to find the common difference, say $d$. We observe that \begin{align*}
a_{101}& + a_{102} + \dots + a_{200} \\
&= (a_1 + 100d)
+ (a_2+ 100d) + \ldots + (a_{100} + 100d) \\
&= a_1 + a_2 + \ldots + a_{100} + 10000d.
\end{align*}Thus $200=100+10000d$  and  $d=\frac{100}{10000}=\boxed{\frac{1}{100}}$.
